title: How does the struggle for life affect consciousness and perception of the inner world?
first_phrase: In this final part of the text, the author discusses the perpetual struggle for survival and the impact it has on consciousness. The individual is constantly focused on external threats and maintaining their existence, leading to a fixation on sensory experiences and a limitation of consciousness. The author argues that even with the awareness of mortality, it is difficult to persuade our innate survival instincts to desist. Therefore, individuals remain fixated on the material conditions of life until the end, where they often succumb. The author uses the Belli's quote to highlight the challenges of relying on organizations or living off others. Ultimately, the author argues that the struggle for survival perpetuates a tyrannical call to consciousness that restricts attention to external threats and consolidates experience around living in the ordinary sensible reality.

last_phrase: In conclusion, the demands of physical life may sharpen our senses and develop our instinct for defense and survival, but they do not nurture spirituality. The concentration on external perceptions can lead to a partial or complete neglect of our inner world, leaving us unaware of its existence and denying its possibility. It is up to us to balance our attention and cultivate our spiritual growth despite the demands of the material world.
